bestBHT.bht: The Samaritan in this story gave the innkeeper two pence, which was equivalent to two day's wages for a laborer. This amount may seem small, but its value at that time was significant and could provide for the man's needs for several days. By assuring the innkeeper that he would repay any additional expenses, the Samaritan demonstrated his trustworthiness. This act of generosity teaches us to rely on Christ and live by faith, as well as use our spiritual gifts to serve others. Christ will eventually reward His ministers for their labor.

Henry Alford: two denarii] Some see in this, two days’ wages. See note on Matt. xx. 2.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: day's wages of a laborer, and enough for several days' support.
Albert Barnes: This may seem a small sum, but we are to remember that that sum was probably ten times as valuable then as now - that is, that it would purchase ten times as much food and the common necessaries of life as the same sum would now.
Besides, it is probable that all the man wanted was 'attention' and kindness, and for all these it was the purpose of the Samaritan to pay when he returned.
Marvin Vincent: Two pence. About thirty - five cents. See on Matthew 20:2.
I will repay. The I is expressed [εγω] , and is emphatic. Trouble him not for the reckoning; I will repay.
Philip Schaff: The sum was sufficient to meet the man’s necessities for some days at least.
It has been inferred from this that the Samaritan was a travelling merchant, who would soon return.
Archibald T. Robertson: Took out (εκβαλων). Second aorist active participle of εκβαλλω. It could mean, 'fling out,' but probably only means 'drew out.' Common verb.
Two pence (δυο δηναρια). About thirty-five cents, but worth more in purchasing power.
I will repay (εγο αποδωσω). Emphatic. What he had paid was merely by way of pledge. He was a man of his word and known to the innkeeper as reliable.
John Gill: Christ does his people, to learn to live by faith upon him.

The gifts and graces of the Spirit of God, to qualify men for the work of the ministry; which both come from the selfsame Spirit of God, and are jointly necessary to fit a man for such service; and are given for the benefit and advantage of the Lord's people.
Christ will certainly come again a second time, to judge both quick and dead; and then he will recompense his ministers, for all their toil and labour, care and expense.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Samaritan in Luke 10:35 gave the innkeeper two pence, which was equal to two day's wages for a laborer. This may seem like a small sum, but in that time it had a much higher purchasing power. The Samaritan emphasized that he would repay any additional expenses upon his return. It is probable that the innkeeper only needed attention and kindness, and the Samaritan intended to reward him for this. The sum given was sufficient to meet the man's needs for several days, showing the Samaritan's care and generosity. Through this story, Christ teaches us to live by faith and rely on him for our provision. He also shows us the importance of using the gifts and graces of the Spirit to serve others, as they come from the same Spirit and are given for the benefit of God's people. In the same way, Christ will return and reward his ministers for their labor and sacrifice.
